The prevalence of underweight children under 5 years increased 
from  24.6%  in  2000  to  27.3%  in  2003,  which  implies  that  about 
5 million  children  under  5  years  have  compromised  growth, 
motor and psycho-social development. Moreover, it is now widely 
recognized that childhood malnutrition will lead to persistent poor 
school enrollment and achievements and pose a long-term threat 
to  adult  productivity  and  girls’  reproductive  health.  Rising 
malnutrition  has  been  observed  in  all  regions  of  Indonesia  but 
has  been  most  pronounced  in  the  eastern  parts  of  the  country, 
the provinces of East Nusa Tenggara and West Nusa Tenggara, 
which have low human development index rankings.  
 
The Ministry of Health (MOH) developed a National Action Plan 
(NAP)  for  the  Prevention  of  Malnutrition  (2005–2009),  which 
aims  to  reduce  the  prevalence  of  underweight  children  under  5 
from 28% in 2005 to below 20% in 2009.  The proposed Project 
will address issues that have led to the decline in overall nutrition 
status and the weakening of nutrition programs and their service 
delivery  through:  (i)  capacity  building  so  nutrition  policies, 
programs  and  surveillance  can  be  developed  at  central, 
provincial  and  district  levels;  (ii)  local  government  capacity 
building  so  integrated  nutrition  services  based  on  local  needs 
can  be  planned  and  delivered;  (iii)  a  revival  of  mobilization  for 
community-based  nutrition  programs;  (iv)  expansion  of  more 
fortification;  and

500,000 pregnant and lactating women. This will provide positive

higher morbidity and mortality.

2. 
A nutrition crisis characterized by severe malnutrition in children under 5 years occurred 
in the eastern Indonesian provinces of East Nusa Tenggara and West Nusa Tenggara in early 
2005. In response, the Government of Indonesia, represented by the Directorate of Community 
Nutrition of the Ministry of Health (MOH), requested ADB to prepare a central nutrition project1 
in six provinces2 suffering from poor nutrition status in children under 5 years.

child mortality (MDG 4), maternal health (MDG 5) and combating HIV/AIDS, malaria and other

Malnutrition in Indonesia remains a significant public health problem for both urban and

enrollment and achievements and pose a long-term threat to girls’ reproductive health and adult 
productivity.

and  feeding  practices  in  young  children  and  the  resulting  high  prevalence  of  underweight

1. 

Challenges 

 
7. 
Decentralization.  Decentralization  resulted  in  an  overall  decline  in  the  quality  of  basic 
health  services,  including  nutrition  programs,  at  hospitals;  district  health  centers  (puskesmas), 
the  first  level  of  clinical  care;  and  integrated  community  services  posts  (posyandu),  where 
growth monitoring and nutrition counseling, immunization, and vitamin A distribution traditionally 
occurred.  While  decentralization  aimed  to  empower  local  institutions  and  local  governments, 
they  were  institutionally  and  financially  unprepared  to  take  over  planning  and  management 
functions. The quality of the nutrition services offered by the puskesmas was adversely affected 
because  the  roles  and  responsibilities  of  nutrition  staff  at  provincial  and  district  levels  had  not 
been  defined  and  staff  had  not  been  trained.  In  addition,  the  nutrition  surveillance  system 
(NSS), which provided essential information not covered by the health information system has 
not been fully operational. The decline in posyandu services over recent years may explain the 
increase in child malnutrition because child weighing and nutritional advice is no longer provided 
and must be obtained from other sources. 
 
8.

of 1997 had a number of consequences for the nutritional status of children. Rapid inflation led 
to  an  increase  in  food  prices  while  real  incomes  declined,  reducing  access  to  food  and  basic 
social services by the poor. To alleviate the social and economic distress caused by the crisis, 
the Government established an emergency intervention, the Social Safety Net (SSN) Program,

Deterioration  in  Procurement  and  Distribution  of  Micronutrients.  Indonesia’s 
micronutrient intervention programs were generally successful until the Asian financial crisis and 
decentralization, which reduced procurement and distribution of micronutrients such as vitamin 
A capsules and iron tablets, and overall household food consumption (because of higher food 
prices). The current prevalence of vitamin A deficiency (VAD) and iron deficiency anemia (IDA) 
remains a concern, given the adverse impact of micronutrient deficiencies on the health status 
and  educability  of  children.  About  50%  of  children  under  5  years  suffer  from  VAD  and  this  is 
associated  with  weaknesses  in  the  biannual  vitamin  A  supplementary  distribution  program.  In 
2001, it was estimated that about 40% of pregnant and lactating women suffered from IDA.14 A 
description of nutrition trends related to malnutrition and obesity is in Appendix 1. 
 
12. 
Inadequate Feeding Practices. Malnutrition’s most serious and lasting damage occurs 
either during pregnancy or in children under 2 years. Child weight at birth in Indonesia is slightly 
below international standards, but deteriorates with age, especially from about 6 months, which 
is when breast feeding becomes inadequate for an infant’s nutritional intake and regular intakes 
of  nutrient-dense  complementary  foods  are  needed.  There  is  a  significant  correlation  between 
low  birth  weight  and  underweight  of  young  children,  reflecting  conditions  of  poverty  and  poor 
food  access  that  affect  pregnant  women  as  well  as  their  infants.15 Exclusive  breast  feeding 
levels are declining in many places, so infants are given fewer opportunities to receive valuable 
nutrients and the protection against infection that can be derived from breast milk.16  
 
13. 
Urbanization and Nutrition Transition. Urbanization exacerbates the transition toward 
more  sedentary  lifestyles,  and  high-fat  diets.  This  may  lead  to  obesity  or  over-nutrition,  a 
potential risk factor for diet-related chronic diseases such as diabetes and heart diseases. The 
causes of the nutrition transition—a term used to describe shifts in diet, health and nutrition that 
occur with modernization—are partly related to the increased consumption of processed foods 
rather than traditional home-made foods among the urban poor.17 The economic costs of over- 
nutrition  and  diet-related  diseases  are  increasingly  equal  to  that  of  malnutrition. 18 More 
knowledge  and  information  about  dietary  quality  is  required  and  nutritious  food  needs  to  be 
made more affordable.

Poor Hygiene and Sanitation. Access to clean water and sanitation continues to be low 
14. 
in  Indonesia.  The  lack  of  access  to  safe  water  and  sanitation  contributes  to  the  incidence  of 
diarrheal disease, which has a detrimental impact on children’s nutritional status. About 11% of 
Indonesian children have diarrhea in any 2-week period. According to National Socoeconomic 
Survey (SUSENAS) data, the percentage of households with access to water has declined from 
51% in 2000 to 48% in 2003, while access to household sanitation facilities increased from 53% 
in 2000 to 57% in 2003.  
 
15.  Weakened  Nutrition  Programs.  The  integrated  community  services  post  (posyandu), 
which  offers  nutrition  services  related  to  infant  and  maternal  child  nutrition,  including  child 
weight  monitoring  and  nutrition  counseling,  was introduced  in  the  1980s.  Generally, posyandu 
played a significant role in the long period of declining malnutrition prevalence in Indonesia. The 
posyandu  are  operated  by  community-based  volunteers  who  receive  training  and  basic 
equipment  (e.g.,  weighing  scales  and  growth  charts).  The  posts  are  supported  by  trained 
nutrition  staff  from  the  sub-district  health  center  (puskesmas).  However,  since  the  late  1990s, 
numerous studies and surveys have indicated that coverage and utilization rates have declined 
because of inadequate service delivery and lack of volunteer support at the community level.19 It 
is  believed  that  less  than  60%  of  puskesmas  currently  employ  any  trained  nutrition  staff, 
severely  reducing  the  level  of  service  support  to  posyandu  and  the  quantity  and  quality  of 
services available at the puskesmas.  

 
16. 
Complementing  the  posyandu,  Indonesia  also  implemented  successful  community-
based nutrition programs such as the Family  Nutrition Improvement  Program (FNIP),20 with its 
focus  on  nutrition  education  and  home  gardening,  throughout  the  1980s  and  1990s.  In  a 
decentralized  environment,  continued  financial  and  leadership  support  for  nutrition  programs 
such as these requires intensive advocacy and communication to local governments and other 
community structures as well as revised approaches that address local constraints (e.g., costs 
and  lack  of  volunteers).  Public  expenditure  on  nutrition  programs 21  has  declined  as  a 
percentage  of  total  health  expenditures  since  the  financial  crisis  and  decentralization.  A 
significant  share  of  the  available  nutrition  budget  is  allocated  to  supplementary  feeding 
programs that are often poorly targeted and subject to leakage and other inefficiencies. These 
financial  commitments  are  made  at  the  expense  of  more  cost-effective  nutrition  interventions, 
such  as  micronutrient  supplementation,  nutrition  education  and  growth  monitoring  and 
counseling,  especially  through  the  posyandu  system,  which  could  lead  to  more  widespread, 
sustained improvements in the nutritional status of young children and women.

18.  Window of Opportunity to Address Malnutrition. International experience shows that 
nutrition  programs  are  among  the  most  cost-effective  health  interventions  available.22 Nutrition 
research  and  programs  are  increasingly  focusing  on  efforts  to  address  malnutrition  during 
pregnancy  and  the  first  2  years  of  life.  Evidence  suggests  that  losses  in  growth  and 
development  during  this  period  are  irreversible  and  have  long-term,  inter-generational 
implications for health and productivity. Conversely, the failure to address malnutrition leads to 
measurable long-term economic losses and, when combined with poor education opportunities, 
can ultimately constrain economic development. 
 
19. 
Food  Fortification.  One  opportunity  that  arises  as  populations  shift  from  consuming 
self-produced foods to processed foods is that processed foods can be fortified to improve the 
intake of vitamins and minerals. Food fortification programs such as salt iodization; fortification 
of wheat flour with iron, zinc, folic acid, other B vitamins; and fortification of palm oil with vitamin 
A  are  important,  highly  cost-effective  ways  of  addressing  micronutrient  deficiencies  for  the 
whole population. In Indonesia further strengthening of such programs is needed.23 In addition 
to the focus on community-based nutrition programs, the Project will provide an opportunity to 
strengthen Indonesia’s national food fortification programs.  
 
20. 
External  Assistance  for  Health  and  Nutrition.  Indonesia  has  received  extensive 
assistance for health and nutrition programs in the last three decades, including major projects 
targeted  specifically  at  nutrition-related  outcomes.    The  World  Bank  has  funded  seven  health 
projects  in  Indonesia  since  1992,  including  the  Iodine  Deficiency  Control  Project  (1997),  Safe 
Motherhood  (1998),  and  Early  Childhood  Development  (1999).  The  governments  of  Australia, 
Japan,  Netherlands,  and  United  States;  the  United  Nations  Children  Fund  (UNICEF);  and  the 
World  Food  Program  (WFP)  have  also  had  important  projects  covering  health  services, 
nutrition,  community  health,  child  survival,  maternal  health,  and  family  planning.  Further 
information on external support for nutrition can be found in Appendix 2.

During  a  health  transition,  the  incidence  of  acute  infectious  disease  and  acute 
malnutrition decline, while rates of chronic diseases and malnutrition rise. Both sets of problems 
continue to co-exist, leading to a “double burden” of nutritional problems, often within the same 
household.5   
 
11. 
The  double  burden  is  more  prevalent  in  urban  than  in  poor  areas,  where  demographic 
changes and disparities are most pronounced.  Malnutrition and obesity are both linked to poor 
dietary  intake  and  limited  diversity.    Low  caloric  and  nutrient  intake  in  children  can  lead  to 
hormonal imbalances that predispose them to obesity and chronic diseases when they age.6 
 
12. 
Early prevention of obesity is a cost-effective public health approach and avoids the high 
social and economic costs of nutrition-related chronic diseases. The emphasis can no longer be 
solely on increasing the quantity of food available to the urban poor; there needs to be a shift 
toward  promoting  good  quality  foods,  as  well  as  to  healthy  activity  patterns  and  feeding 
behaviors.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Indonesia: 
Improving  nutrition  is  essential  to  reducing  extreme  poverty.  Undernutrition 1  and  micronutrient  malnutrition  are 
themselves direct indicators of poverty and may be linked to income poverty. Evidence suggests that the prevalence 
of malnutrition is often two or three times higher among the poorest income quintile than among the highest quintile.2 
Improving nutrition is pro-poor and increases the income-earning potential of the poor. Poverty is associated with poor 
diets,  physically  demanding  labor,  unhealthy  environments  and  high  fertility.  Malnutrition  reduces  health,  education 
and income, thus perpetuating poverty. Nutrition programs are very cost-effective. The 2004 Copenhagen Consensus 
of  eminent  economists  concluded  that  the  returns  from  investing  in  micronutrient  programs  are  second  only  to  the 
returns from fighting HIV/AIDS.  
 
Malnutrition  is  endemic  in  Indonesia,  despite  improved  socioeconomic  indicators,  including  the  incidence  of  poverty. 
While poverty contributes to malnutrition, particularly severe malnutrition, knowledge and customs of child caring and 
child  feeding  are  important  determinants  of  malnutrition.  In  Indonesia,  significant  levels  of  malnutrition  are  not  only 
related to the poor but also to the non-poor (suggesting that not only  low incomes but also education, behavior and 
attitudes,  child  care,  and  child  feeding  are  important  determinants  of  malnutrition).  Community-based  programs 
targeted at children under 2 years are cost-effective in preventing undernutrition.

nutrition. Absolute poverty is a poor proxy for nutritional status, as the income distribution in Indonesia is very flat with 
60%  of  the  population  clustered  around  the  poverty  line.  While  markets  are  failing  to  address  malnutrition  (because 
many households cannot afford adequate food or health care), malnutrition occurs also among the non-poor because 
of ignorance of the breast feeding practices for young children and pregnant women and because growth faltering and 
micronutrient deficiencies cannot be easily detected by caretakers.  

Other factors have a significant impact on  malnutrition, including customary feeding  and child rearing practices, and 
hygiene  and  diarrheal  diseases. To  some  extent,  Prevalence  of  diarrheal  diseases  is  correlated  with  access  to  safe 
water.  Consumption  of  prepared  foods  increases  with  income,  including  food  with  little  nutritional  value.  In  crowded 
urban  areas,  lack  of  adequate  kitchen  facilities  and  the  high  cost  of  cooking  fuel  make  purchase  of  prepared  or 
processed  foods,  even  for  the  very  young  children,  a  cheap  option.  Snack  foods  are  cheap  and  represent  a  large 
proportion of household expenditure at all expenditure levels but particularly at lower income levels.   

The  Project’s  poverty  strategy  is  founded  on  targeting  districts  with  chronically  high  malnutrition  rates,  taking  into 
account population size and relative levels of income poverty and channeling services through the institutions used by 
the  poor,  such  as  health  centers  (puskesmas)  and  revitalization  of  community-based  services  (posyandu).    The 
Project brings nutrition services closer to the community and will make them more accessible to the income poor. The 
community empowerment component is intended to enable communities how to take responsibility for the nutritional 
status of their children and mothers.  This component is also expected to demonstrate that community empowerment 
is both affordable and effective. Strengthening nutrition services helps to ensure that improved nutritional services and 
advocacy will continue beyond the project.

D.  Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
The  Project  is  self-targeted  since  it  aims  to  improve  the  nutritional  status  of  pregnant  and  lactating  women  and 
children.  It  addresses  the  specific  needs  of  women  in  their  reproductive  and  primary  caretaker  roles.  Men  are  not 
excluded from the project, as they are sometimes caretakers and decide on household priorities. Specific targets have 
been set for component 2 to ensure gender balance in the training of nutritionists and other health staff as well as the 
engagement of community facilitators. Women will probably be the carers of malnourished and sick children and will 
thus bear the financial burden of health care costs. The achievement of the Project’s purpose and objectives will have 
benefits for both women and men. Changing attitudes and behavior towards nutrition, child feeding and child care in 
both  women  and  men  will  directly  benefit  women  and  their  children.  The  communication  component,  peer-to-peer 
education, and other interpersonal communication such as nutrition counseling will directly address these perceptions 
and  behaviors  as  they  affect  women  and  children.    The  project  design  is  based  on  careful  consideration  of  gender 
issues  and  ensures  women’s  participation  in  all  activities.  Gender-specific  features  will  be  supported  by  loan 
covenants.  

Women  are  primary  focus  of  the  Project  since  their  nutrition  during  pregnancy  and  breast  feeding  is  key  as  is  their 
responsibility for their households' dietary choices and food preparation.  

Project  investments  accrue  first  to  women  and  then  to  the  family  and  the  community  as  a  whole.  Integrating  and 
prioritizing  policies  that  deliver  the  greatest  nutritional  benefits  will  ensure  that  women  in  their  roles  as  mothers  and 
children will get optimal benefits from government nutrition programs.  

As  nutrition  services  are  mainly  delivered  through  the  health  system  a  comprehensive  review  of  programs  and 
protocols,  improvement  of  training  materials,  and  training  medical  and  nursing  staff  in  nutritional  services  including 
breast-feeding  promotion  and  in  outreach  programs  is  required.  Targets  will  be  set  for  ensuring  gender  balance  in 
training of medical and nursing professionals who are primarily female, taking into account their areas of specialization 
and  responsibilities.  Community  facilitators  experienced  in  nutrition  (mainly  female)  and  in  sanitation  (mainly  male) 
bridge  the  formal  health  system  and  outreach  programs  and  the  community.  Proposed  loan  covenants  ensure  that 
50% of community facilitators will be female.  

The outreach programs are interventions related to child feeding and child care, hygiene and sanitation, breast feeding 
and  links  to  essential  health  services,  including  home  visits  by  midwives  and  posyandu  cadre  and  referrals.  The 
programs  are  delivered  by  women  as  nurses,  midwives,  and  volunteer  members  of  the  posyandu  who  are  largely 
female.  In  addition,  the  community  facilitators  will  work  with  the  community  to  engage  the  community  nutrition 
awareness  and  promote  community  level  nutrition  enhancing  activities  such  as  improving  environmental  cleanliness 
and  access  to  water  or  providing  space  for  nutrition  related  activities.  The  community  facilitators  will  work  with  key 
stakeholders, mothers, fathers, teachers, community leaders, and the community at large. 
 
Grants  will  be  provided  to  communities  to  engage  them  in  improving  the  nutritional  status  of  pregnant  and  lactating 
mothers  and  children  in  the  community.  Through  awareness  promotion  and  grants,  communities  will  be  able  to 
address  key  nutrition  such  as  enhancing  the  services  of  the  posyandu,  school  feeding,  child-care,  or  improving 
environmental cleanliness and access to water.
